concepts.title: Deployment Flow
concepts.simpleExplanation: Deploying code to NetSuite is like moving furniture into a new house. You pack your code (bundle), transport it (deploy), and unpack it in the right rooms (NetSuite account).
concepts.technicalDetails: The deployment process involves: 1) Building your project, 2) Bundling files according to deploy.xml, 3) Validating against NetSuite, 4) Uploading files and creating objects, 5) Installing SuiteApp if applicable.
concepts.realWorldExample: Like deploying a website: you write code locally, build it, then push it to a server where users can access it.

concepts.title: SPA Architecture
concepts.simpleExplanation: A Single Page Application (SPA) is like a smart TV remote. The remote (client) talks to the TV (server) to get what you need, but you don't need to change the channel by going to a new page.
concepts.technicalDetails: SPAs use client-side routing, state management, and server-side APIs. The client handles UI rendering while the server provides data and business logic.
concepts.realWorldExample: Like Gmail - the page doesn't reload when you open an email, it just updates the content dynamically.

concepts.title: SDF Project Structure
concepts.simpleExplanation: An SDF project is like a well-organized filing cabinet. Each drawer (folder) has a specific purpose: scripts go here, objects go there, files go in another place.
concepts.technicalDetails: SDF projects follow a specific structure: src/FileCabinet for files, src/Objects for custom objects, src/AccountConfiguration for settings, and manifest.xml for project metadata.
concepts.realWorldExample: Like a restaurant kitchen - ingredients (files) have specific places, recipes (scripts) are organized, and the menu (manifest) describes what's available.
